author: Shivy
title: Received the COVID vaccine
body: South lakes vaccination centre was efficiently run all staff were professional and pleasant. My school health nurse Danielle was reassuring and proficient in her approach to giving me the vaccine. As a health worker myself I am well aware of the importance of supporting vaccination for children and babies but I myself feel this is the most proactive thing we can all do to suppress this pandemic. Overall a very good experience today

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Biopsy86BT
title: All of the staff were very good.
body:
I recently had a biopsy taken from my knee by Mr Annan at the Victoria Hospital.  
All of the staff were very good.  
In particular Kerry made me feel so at ease and answered any questions that I had.  
I cannot thank her enough for going above and beyond her duty of care.

author: sf1988
title: Excellent & Thorough Care
body: I fell unwell just before Christmas and was referred to a clinic at Clackmannanshire Health Centre. I was seen by Dr Monaghan who was absolutely fantastic. I have worked in the NHS for over 10 years and can truthfully say I’ve never experienced such thorough care and attention. Dr Monaghan’s manner was completely professional as well as empathetic and she made me feel at ease from the outset. She referred me to the hospital to undergo several tests as she wanted to be precautious and rule out anything further. Over the festive period, she called to check up on me and saw me again at her clinic in Falkirk Community Hospital. Since then, she wrote to my GP to advise that further tests were needed which have now been actioned. I cannot thank Dr Monaghan enough for the care I received, she is one of a kind. Keep up the good work! !

author: Catewee
title: Recent A&E visit
body:
Just wanted to say a big thankyou to all the staff at A&E.  
After a visit, yesterday, despite how busy they obviously were, I found everyone I came into contact with to be very kind and attentive.  
I was reassured that attending had been the correct decision in the circumstances, treated and advice given re future management.

author: Jill5796
title: I cannot express how grateful I am.
body:
Health workers make the worst patients we really do. I was anxious about coming into hospital as I was feeding my 5 month old baby and wasn’t sure how this would work with the current situation however I needed had worried.  
From the moment we stepped into A&E and over to ward 32 and to emergency theatres I knew I was in the best hands the nurses, doctors, theatre staff, porters, hcsw, domestics, surgeons and anaesthetists every single one of u made my family and I feel safe and u guys literally saved my life!  
I cannot express how grateful I am to u all and how quickly you all worked together to get me what I needed. U are all a credit to the hospital and to our nhs! Proud as punch to be part of the nhsggc family.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: leoqj94
title: Assessment of mild chest pain
body: I attended a self referral Cardiac Investigation Unit based at Altnagelvin Hospital, Derry/Londonderry. I was promptly seen by an excellent staff member called Andrew. I had a complete range of tests including an ECG. Andrew took the time to explain all that he was doing and checked that I was understanding it all. He will now follow up my results with a consultation with a Cardiologist. The whole experience was very good and speedy. I hope this unit gets the support it needs to carry out this vital work.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: CookC81
title: Good service from local GP
body: I had a positive covid-19 test result on the Friday. A GP from the Elms practice called me at 18. 30 on the Saturday evening to check in on me and how I was feeling. He explained that the practice Dr's had personally purchased sats monitors to loan to patients and wanted to make sure people were aware of symptoms to be concerned about. He was very reassuring. I felt the service went above and beyond, my husband for example, registered at a different practice, has heard nothing.

author: Ak1983
title: Myself and covid
body:
On advice from doctors I needed checked out in A&E. As it was during doctors hour I had to get triaged over telephone, manner of the gentle was noting sort nice n easy to speak to he then got a doctor from A&E who again was so nice understanding and took no chances sent ambulance crew.  
They arrived with smiles good manner sense of calm checked me over said your coming with us even on during conversation was great which made journey to Craigavon a whole lot shorter. They couldn't have done anymore for me. Into Craigavon the nurse was so welcoming and again made time to ask about me while carrying out her duties never once did I panic cos I was expecting n potentially had covid. The staff had a sense of calm as if I was the only one there turns out I had covid and that never made a difference they still has the same amount of time for me nó difference in their care for me.  
I was admitted for 2 days needed fluids n steriods to boost me the Porter was coming to end of his shift and he could still managed to have chat n laugh on the spin to the ward honestly cannot thank them enough for their professionalism their time their care truly truly amazing people each and everyone of them it takes them all.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Clibro
title: Wonderful staff and treatment
body: I had a couple of lumps removed from my neck and back at the Dermatology unit.   A few little scratches when the anaesthetic went in but felt nothing after that.   When the anaesthetic wore off – no pain. Brilliant friendly staff who obviously care about their patients.   A big thank you to all involved.

author: Gratefulcarer
title: Tremendous support and care.
body:
My husband was discharged from Craigavon Hospital in October, following a stroke and was referred to the Community Stroke Team. The following day, the physiotherapist , Kathryn and occupational therapist, Margaret, visited him and assessed his needs. From the outset they were both very professional, helpful and compassionate and it is clear that they see the person behind the disability. Kathryn had her last visit with us today and while we are delighted with the progress that my husband has made, we will both miss Kathryn’s visits to our home. She has given him great confidence with his mobility which is helping him to be more independent. She has been like a breath of fresh air.  
Equally Margaret has been a tremendous support in helping to arrange for a handrail at our front door, giving advice on a wheelchair and getting a bed rail , these things are making such a difference for my husband at a practical level and making his life a little easier. Margaret was always very approachable and helpful and we are indebted to her for all her help.  
We also had great help and input from Danielle, the social worker who gave great advice and arranged for carers to come in from the Trust Domicilliary Care Team and also arranged for social workers to get in touch with me. Each and every one of the carers who come in have been a great help and support and continue to be so. They are so professional, caring and compassionate in how they interact with my husband and their support is a great help to me, as I am the main carer for my husband. Danielle also recommended that I join in via zoom with a Stroke support group, I found this great as it was very informative and helped me to be able to speak to other people who were in the same situation as we were.  
Dr McCaffrey has been very attentive in following up on my husband’s progress and has contacted us a few times to check how he is doing, we have really appreciated her ongoing care and advice.  
In summary the Community Stroke Team and Trust Domiciliary Care Team have been a great help, they have enabled my husband to make great progress following his stroke and have supported me as his carer. He is making great progress and is slowly gaining back his independence with the help of all these lovely people. Thank you so much to each and every one of them.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: Jelo92
title: Caring and compassionate.
body: I was admitted to S12 in Doncaster Royal infirmary after being seen in the out if hours GP service for abdominal pain. The nurses, health care assistants and doctors that I was treated by were caring and compassionate throughout my 4 day stay with them. I eventually had to have surgery for appendicitis and I was nervous as I'd never had a general anaesthetic before. They reassured me about the procedure and made me more at ease. The ward was clean, and even through the pandemic I felt safe at all times. Thank you to all of the team on S12.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: browserhn47
title: I look forward to Oakhaven
body:
I look forward to going to Oakhaven the staff are cheerful and will listen to any problems you have  
I enjoy doing the quiz and also the exercises  
I have learnt a lot going to the room

author: corvuscw44
title: So lucky to have this service
body:
We are so lucky to have Oakhaven on our doorstep! What an amazing place. When you need support, help - a listening ear.  
My partner goes to the day centre (when allowed) on a Friday and loves it and it is so helpful for me to have a few hours to myself!  
The carers days are also so invaluable of the 'Staff; are so lovely/caring and provide support - even calling weekly.  
There is also 'complimentary medicine' if required.  
I think what they do is so wonderful and I appreciate everything they do.  
As for improving - it may be very difficult as they already provide quality above and beyond. Some days I have been and feel very down and your spirits are soon lifted with the chat and company there.

author: slidedg43
title: My pharmacist
body: My story. I am thanking the pharmacist, who provides a pharmacy service at my local GP practice. He is welcoming and easy to talk to, he makes you feel at ease. He is kind and caring, listen to you and work with you to provide that is the best care for you. He is the best and very knowledgeable and loves his work and it shows. I saw thanks again.

author: Mumof5*
title: Helping keep our little family safe
body:
My first experience of the PRM was in 2017 when I was pregnant with my 3rd baby. I had my previous pregnancies under the care of NHS Ayrshire and Arran. I have to say that the night before my first appointment I didn’t sleep. I had built a really good relationship with my community midwife and worried that I would feel the same support in Glasgow.  
My first appointment was with my community midwife Julie. The relief I felt after meeting her and knowing that she would be looking after us. My baby was measuring big but my previous babies were quite big so I didn’t worry as I felt safe and trusted that staff that they knew what they were doing. My little girl was born January 2018 and a healthy 10lbs 10oz. Unfortunately I sustained a 3rd degree tear and had to go to theatre. My midwives Sam and Kirsty came to theatre and really put me at ease.  
Fast forward to September 2019 and I was pregnant again. I knew something didn’t feel right. I phoned EPAS and unfortunately was met with a midwife who offered little support. I was told on several occasions during the phone call that I shouldn’t be under the care of the PRM and she tried to transfer me to the QEUH. I tried to tell her that my previous care was in the PRM and I hadn’t changed address but I was told that if I was to be seen regarding my concerns then I had to attend the QEUH. I decided to wait it out until my community midwife appointment with Julie again.  
I can’t explain the relief when I saw her and she immediately arranged an early scan. Unfortunately this pregnancy ended in a miscarriage. The midwives in EPAS that day were really caring and helpful and took the time to discuss our options. We were devastated and Julie took the time to check how we were coping.  
Thankfully I became pregnant soon after and had Julie look after us again. At every appointment she took the time to listen to my concerns and wipe away my tears as this pregnancy was the most stressful I had experienced. Add a pandemic into the mix too. Unfortunately my husband couldn’t attend any of my appointments but I felt supported whenever I had to attend the PRM.  
I was asked to consider an elective c-section after having a large baby in 2018 and sustaining a tear. I was worried at the prospect of this as I had never experienced it with my previous pregnancies but the doctor really took the time to explain the procedure and allowed time for me to make my final decision. I opted for it in the end and the theatre staff that day were amazing. My little boy was born in September 2020 and they took every opportunity to involve my husband which meant so much to him as he had missed out on all our scans and appointments.  
A special mention to Lorna who was lovely. I was in hospital for a few days after and received help and support from the student midwife to help establish breastfeeding. Once discharged I was cared for again by Julie. I feel really lucky to have had her as she really is amazing at her job. I really just wanted to thank the PRM for helping keep our little family safe.

author: lacertafs79
title: Life changing
body:
SLT service running on Nottinghamshire's acute wards provided through assessment of long-standard communication difficulties and the tools to mitigate them.  
Staff are passionate, kind and dedicated to their patients.  
Thank you so much

author: mineralfn37
title: Helping us prepare for the uncertain future
body:
My husband and I were introduced to the Hospice Day Care centre by the palliative care team following my husbands long stay in hospital with sepsis.  
Initially we were visited and supported by a community nurse who helped us both to prepare for the uncertain future.  
The hospice day centre was a true lifeline for my husband. His weekly visit gave him  
-something to look forward to each week.  
-the company and companionship of other gentlemen.  
-a weekly conversation with professional about his health.  
-I could release knowing he was being well looked after  
The carers monthly support group gave me  
-Time to focus on myself/time for me to reflect on my needs.  
-An opportunity to share my concerns with the other people who understood what I was going through.  
-An opportunity to learn from more experienced carers

author: chamaeleonqk76
title: Dealing with addiction
body: Had a great time, with key worker. Dealing with addiction in a better way

author: earmarkpp55
title: Helped to rebuild his life
body:
Really went well to help further his life  
The staff they spoke too really helped to his partner and himself, to rebuild the life,

author: guideyq73
title: A gem of a nurse
body:
I attended this unit last week and found Nurse Michelle a gem of a nurse I was triaged first class 110%  
God bless all you NHS. Working.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Miss DMU
title: She put my mind at ease.
body: When I needed to contact Rheumatology Dept regarding a letter sent to me, I  was apprehensive as due to Covid it makes you think whether you need to or not.   The call was answered by the wonderful Jackie she put my mind at ease & talked me through what she was going to do, made sure I was ok with message she would forward.   At no time did I feel I had wasted anyone's time & for me that is a huge thing. Thank you.

author: Amy77
title: Coil removal and re fitted
body:
The staff I had with during my procedure made me feel relaxed and calm and were very friendly making me feel better about the situation. They cared for my needs brilliantly as I have back problems they end t above and beyond to keep me pain free and comfortable.  
When having my coil removed and then another fitted I didn’t feel a thing and the nurse explained to me everything she was doing and kept me calm and relaxed.  
Overall the experience I had was above and beyond by all 3 members of staff who were helping with me procedure!!! I would like to thank them and give them the praise they deserve. I definitely would be happy to return to their care in the future!  
I attended pilgrim hospital gynae department, the nurse practitioner was nurse Palmer and the other nurse was called Amy and the healthcare was called Val they are all a credit to your team and service.

author: kingsway
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Home Talk Plus Consultations
body: I liked the sessions and going to the park, the strategies were easy to follow and I was comfortable to say if I didn't understand something.

author: ClincolnU
title: Hospital appointment
body:
I was asked on both my pre-appointment phone call and letter to arrive NO MORE than 5 minutes prior to my appointment, assumably to reduce the amount of people waiting together to be seen and to limit people's time spent at a hospital during the pandemic. I arrived at the time of my appointment, to be greeted and directed by absolutely nobody. Once sat down I witnessed others arrive and be greeted, point out their appointment was 25+ minutes away, and be sat down along with everyone else. Both myself and at least 2 other patients were asked 3-5 times to repeat our name.  
I was advised over the phone and by letter/leaflet that it would be a very quick procedure, 5 minutes in fact, and I'd be in and out in 20 minutes. My appointment was at 9:40am. I was called through for the procedure at 10:30am. I was already anxious about going to the hospital and about having the procedure so being made to sit in a waiting room thinking about nothing but the procedure for 50 minutes with 7 other people in the near vicinity did nothing but worsen my anxiety.  
My letter/leaflet said not to worry about arriving with a full bladder as this wouldn't be needed and actually wasn't preferable for the procedure yet one of the first things I was asked to do was provide a urine sample.  
To top it all off the consultant told me (right before conducting the procedure) that it wasn't really necessary and shouldn't have been arranged given my relevant medical history leading up to it but that we'd continue if I wanted to. Considering I’d had a Covid test, isolated for 3 days, taken half a day off work, lost sleep worrying about the procedure and spent the last hour feeling sick waiting for it, I didn’t really feel there was a decision to be made here. What this did mean was that I felt backed into a corner of going through with quite an intrusive procedure that could very well lead to infection when it apparently wasn’t really necessary.  
All in all a shocking experience and I can only hope now that I get no illness or infections as a result of having a procedure I apparently didn't require.

author: SART
title: Support and care at A&E
body:
I attended Forth Valley Royal Accident and Emergency Department following an fall on ice in my back garden in early January. My Husband and a few of my neighbours had managed to get me into the car via a makeshift stretcher as the all the ambulances were busy and there would be a significant wait.  
The Department was extremely busy due to it being particularly icy outside. I was in a terrible state and felt extremely vulnerable. The staff were excellent, quickly processing me and getting me to X-ray, where once again the staff were extremely kind and understanding.  
On returning from X-ray, the pain relief I had taken at home was starting to wear off, and I suffered a panic attack. The staff came to my aid and offered assistance and treatment to calm me, quickly taking me to have my foot manipulated into place. I was then processed and taken to Ward B23. All staff were excellent, having to do this on your own without support from another person is horrendous, but at no time did I feel unsupported. In all honesty I don’t think I could have received better care.  
Thank you for your support and care.

author: Deedee18
title: Being a Covid inpatient
body: I have been an inpatient for the last 2 weeks in wards 6 and 7. I was initially taken to A&E with severe Covid symptoms. From that first moment in A&E till being discharged tomorrow I can honestly say hand on heart that I would not have received any better care anywhere else. I know this for sure as I have been an inpatient before in different hospitals and I also work on a ward in another hospital myself. The quick reaction of medical staff with my treatment, to total professionalism and dedication to my care from all nursing staff, to the cleanliness and friendliness of domestic staff has been above and beyond anything I could have hoped for. I also would like to thank on-site kitchen staff who made meals that were tasty and brought my appetite back, it was a longing at every meal rather than a dread and my family didn’t have to worry about me not eating properly. In a world where it’s so easy to find the negatives in everything, I can honestly say I have nothing but positivity from Wishaw General. Everyone who works there should be so proud. Well done everyone! ! !

author: colinpian
title: covid vaccination
body: Just received my Covid 19 vaccination at Craigavon today. It was an incredible heart warming experience from beginning to end. From I arrived in the carpark it took one hour until I was driving out. Lots of staff in attendance, indicating where to go and what to do. Greeted warmly and asked to wear one of their masks and was quite happy for me to wear it on top of my own. Registration was totally behind perspex screens and I was asked to wipe down area and pen I used with wipes provided. Then it was a case of distanced queueing and then sitting in a waiting area for my turn. I was again asked to wipe down the seat I had used before being shown to an individual nurse station which was totally private. Nurse was very informative and took time to check my details and personal medical history. She prepared the vaccine and then asked another nurse to check it and then it was over. I was shown to a sitting area to wait for fifteen minutes and then indicated to go outside after sanitising again. I was treated as an individual and there was an air efficiency and care. Well done HSC Northern Ireland, I couldn't fault it.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Butter-Scotch
title: My Journey with Covid 19
body:
I was feeling unwell for about a week. I couldn't get a breath. My daughter made an appointment for me to get tested. My result was Covid positive. She contacted Dal-Doc and the Doctor told her to get me into hospital ASAP.  
My Daughter took me to Antrim ED. I spent a night there in a side room. I did have a bed though. The staff must of been nice because I would of remembered if they were rude. I was taken to A3. Every day I felt worse. I couldn't get a breath. They put me on CPAP. I felt very comfortable because it helped me to breathe. I don't remember much because I felt so unwell. When I started to improve, the doctor told me I had been very unwell, and that it would take a while for my breathing to get better again. The staff were very kind and approachable. The ward was very clean. I have nothing but praise for the staff. They treated me well. The only issue I had was that they lost my denture. They said they must of fallen in the laundry. I was really annoyed about that.  
They brought me to Whiteabbey Nightingale in an ambulance. The ambulance crew were very good. The staff have been trying to get me on my feet here and they're getting me to walk with oxygen on. The staff are great and very helpful. The food is lovely. I eat everything they give me... nearly the plate too. I still can't smell my food, but I can taste it.  
I couldn't of gone home at the time I came here so the Nightingale has benefited me in my mobility.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

links.id: LACK OF CARE REGARDING PERSONAL BELONGINGS

author: lovepb86
title: Receiving covid vaccine
body: The person administering my vaccine did not check over my information, ask me about allergies or other contraindications to receiving the vaccine. They did not get the drawn up volume checked with a second person and administered the injection too high up my arm, causing significant pain and mobility difficulties for over a week. I find this all very concerning. Having experience giving vaccinations myself, in my opinion this is not correct procedure.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: equuleushp86
title: Intensive Care - forever thankful
body:
I was admitted to the ICU with severe sepsis and multi-organ failure. I would like to pass on my sincere thank you to some of the specific people who saved my life when they took over my breathing, Dr Tom, Dr Ross, ITU nurses Linda and Jackie also Mark and Craig who without a doubt saved my life.  
Dr Tom went above and beyond that night to save my life, he never left the bedside. I ended up going to Aberdeen for ECMO, Dr Ross said without a doubt that if it hadn’t of been for them I would not be here today.  
Both of the doctors mentioned went out of their way to care for me especially when I was frightened about certain medical procedures such as my tracheotomy coming out. Dr Ross sat beside me for a couple of hours persuading me that no matter what he would take care of me.  
The whole team in the ICU at the Western saved me and I will be forever thankful for them giving me a second chance at life!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Weeeve7
title: Gastroscopy procedure
body:
I was very anxious about having this procedure, especially having to make the decision on whether I should be brave and have the anaesthetic spray or have the sedation which involves a longer recovery period. However my concerns were alleviated by Nurse Shona who greeted me warmly and explained the procedure and addressed all my concerns. This undoubtedly gave me confidence in making my decision to have the anaesthetic spray. I am very grateful to her as I definitely made the right decision. I was still a little anxious though, which I am sure is natural. However, once I was taken into the treatment room and Mr Naqvi, Consultant Surgeon introduced himself and his team I felt more at ease and knew I was in good hands. During the procedure I was caringly reassured at every stage that everything was going well.  
I cannot thank Mr Naqvi and his team enough for the professional care they showed me. NHS Scotland at its best. Thank you Mr Naqvi and the Team.

author: equuleushp86
title: Saved my life
body: I was admitted with a bleed from my stoma I was quickly seen by on-call surgeon Dr Smith who decided I need the bleed cauterised in theatre, the operation went extremely smoothly but afterward I became septic and ended up in the intensive care unit, the team came to see me the next day so Dr Smith and Dr Granitsiosis wondered what they had missed but to this day I believe it was just a coincidence. I ended up in a coma and on ECMO the urology team undoubtedly saved my life and have done on a number of occasions in the last five months, I would like to thank them individually for what they have done for me a special thank you to Dr Smith, Dr Granitsiosis, Dr Larid, Dr Mains and Dr Good they have all played a part to get me through the last five months, I would also like to thank the registrars Dr Gallagher, Dr Boyle and Sammy who all played a part in the last five months of helping me through this. I would like to thank every member of ward 56 who without a shadow of a doubt saved me I will be forever grateful to yous. I would like to thank nurse practitioners Lorraine and Angela who basically went above and beyond for me in times of need, I will never forget what you all did for me yous deserve a medal for saving me from a certain death more than once!

author: Kez1
title: Covid vaccine
body: The nurse I was with was super lovely and great! She was fab. The location was running about 45 minutes behind time though.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Chocky59
title: Covid Vaccination
body: Very well organised and planned for this vaccination programme. Plenty of staff to ask if you have any questions. Cleaning being done of chairs that you wait your 15 mins on ready to have next appointment.

author: Oglvie
title: Covid Vaccination
body: Last week I had my 1st Covid Vaccination at the Taunton Racecourse. I have to say how well organised everything was. All the people involved were extremely helpful, the nurse and the Dr who were there put me at my ease and everything went off really well. Since coming back home I have felt perfectly well.

author: MarF2021
title: Covid19 vaccination
body: Very efficient and friendly staff. Very professional

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: November52
title: Impressive and efficient care from NHS 24
body:
I contacted NHS 24 with a concern about my finger and hand that I had cut on a tin a couple of days previously. My finger was becoming more swollen, red and hot and this was spreading up my hand.  
My call was answered quickly and information taken kindly and efficiently by the call handler. I was transferred to speak to a nurse practitioner who checked out some more detailed information. I was then referred to my local hub and received a text for a video consultation. I had this with Fran who again was very kind and helpful. She arranged antibiotics for me to pick up at my local hospital. The whole process to 2 hours from the start of my call to me picking up the antibiotics. Everyone I had contact with was kind, helpful and thoroughly professional. I was incredibly impressed by the whole process, thank you.

author: Blackie55
title: Heroes and angels
body:
My Wife had an aneurysm on her aorta which ruptured on Boxing Night, she was taken by ambulance to The Queen Elizabeth. She was taken to theatre and operated on by Mr Hussy and his team, thankfully, due to the skills of these wonderful surgeons, my Wife survived the operation. She subsequently spent 3 weeks in the ICU and is now recovering in the renal unit at The Queen Elizabeth. I just wanted to express my heartfelt thanks to Mr Hussy, his team of doctors and nurses who assisted with the operation and all the fantastic doctors and nurses who took care of my wife in the ICU.  
She is now in a specialist renal ward (ward 4D) the staff there are doing a fantastic job in looking after Sheila, assisting with her physical and mental recovery. You are all my heroes and angels, I will always be grateful to you.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Lgrim1
title: Mental health services for Northlands
body:
I had been under the care of northlands and the recovery team for just over three years. Up until October 2020 it had been good and I had made a lot of progress under the supervision of my previous doctor. Since then the service has been abysmal, some personal circumstances led my mental health to deteriorate. I had repeatedly tried to contact my new consultant to try and get some help, to no avail. I had one appointment with the new consultant where I felt they were very unhelpful, not listening to current symptoms and adamant I waited until I had talking therapy (at least 6 month waiting list). I feel this is unacceptable, the symptoms I was having placed me off work at the beginning of November and some intervention was needed.  
I then went back to my gp to try and get help from them, they have been fantastic. I have now been out of work for two months and have received no care from northlands. This was after repeated attempts from me to contact, and from my gp. None of which was listened to. I would get called back by under qualified nurses who I felt didn’t know anything about my case and could offer no solution. I have had to chase them for call backs all the time, and in nearly three months have spoke to my consultant once. My GP has repeatedly been in contact with them to get a medication review and an assessment, also ignored.  
Last week they said it had just been put on the system and I would hear back this week, instead I got a letter of discharge. What I really want to know is why it has taken them nearly 3 months to discharge me? I’ve lost income, haven’t worked and in financial difficulty now. I repeatedly tried to complain to the managers at northlands, no one ever called me back, I tried on at least 3 occasions. I’m now in the process of formally complaining to the CCG.  
I am disgusted by the quality, and lack thereof, of care and those involved should be ashamed.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: handsetby86
title: A focus for my week
body:
I love it, it gives me a focus for my week, volunteer drives are so helpful  
look forward to my weekly visit

author: indigoxm74
title: Outpatient services
body:
I have attended Oakhaven as an outpatient since June 2017. For me it is everything. A happy and caring place to use, with the most caring and helpful staff and volunteers.  
Without Oakhaven, life for me would be very dull.  
I can't thank them enough for all they do.

author: Roobdoob
title: A well run unit
body:
I attended to endoscopy unit for gastroscopy and colonoscopy , the staff nurse Grace who did my admission and then looked after me in recovery , explained everything that would happen was so gentle and kind in her manner and her clear explanations it made me much less anxious about the procedures .  
All the other staff I came in contact with were very kind and caring though through the effects of sedation I dont remember any names.  
I have no suggestions for improvement, this is a well run unit with kind and caring staff.

title: Understanding Registrar
body: I had to attend the Hallamshire Neurology Department for investigation in January and was fortunate to be put in the care of a wonderful Registrar. So many times previously I had been rushed through GPs and hospital appointments, feeling frustrated and leaving without answers but this time the Registrar took time to thoroughly investigate me, approached  me with respect and understanding and took on board my concerns and questions. There is a heap of difference between hearing and really listening and I felt he really listened. I had chance to ask questions and he put my mind at rest. Added to that I was given a variety of solutions to think about, something, I hadn't had before. I was really thankful to be given the time and respect and my condition not dismissed, especially during this immensely busy time for health care professionals. The nurses on the ward and during blood testing were also lovely and supportive despite all the pressures they were under. On the whole this was a very positive experience

readBy.name: Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: pepperpp65
title: Excellent experiences
body:
My experiences at Oakhaven have been excellent  
I come one day per fortnight, the transport services are spot on and I look forward to coming to see all your happy faces

author: maptomischief
title: Support from staff
body:
I have been under John's care since coming into the service in November. Throughout that time he has been available to talk to me whenever I have called and has dealt with some challenging behaviour from myself at times too. He has been extremely supportive and think he deserves recognition for his stellar work.  
I also want to add that when coming back to the service Claire also took time out of her busy schedule to speak to me one on one before I was assessed, this made me feel very comfortable as she was my first key worker when I first engaged with the service.  
Overall, thank you to all the staff at CGL Halton for your ongoing support.

author: starhj93
title: Waiting for MRI
body:
We were on Harlyn ward waiting for an MRI scan. Disappointed there was no toys even though we asked for some we were told they were restricted.  
8 month old was hysterical and upset but if there was toys could have made her happier.

author: correspondencerw48
title: A wonderful experience
body: A wonderful covid safe experience at Lings Bar hospital. The memory clinic staff had made every effort to make sure my mother and I felt safe and comfortable from start to finish. Many thanks

author: sagittariustw47
title: Covid 19 vaccination
body:
I am 76 years old and attended Belgrave Medical Centre, Asline Road, Sheffield S8 to get my Covid 19 jab. Fantastic experience! Greeted by local community people we know and recognise. Despite heavy snow, great care taken and all feeling safe.  
Well done local NHS and Sheffield Public Health team.  
PS I tried to do the survey (www.surveymonkey.co.uk/r/Sheffieldvaccine) but couldn't access this website.

author: earthkg76
title: My social worker helped me
body:
I have a social worker. I had to shield over lockdown. My social worker gave me information on covid and things to contact the deaf community. She helped me with shopping. She helped me with post and talked to me through the window. The equipment officer also helped me when I had problems with my equipment. Good help.  
**Video of story in BSL **  
This is a translation by a BSL translator  
[https://vimeo.com/839982845](https://vimeo.com/839982845)  
**Video of story in ISL**  
This is a translation by an ISL translator  
[https://vimeo.com/839982889](https://vimeo.com/839982889)

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: lynxyp95
title: Genius in every sense
body:
I had reason to attend assessment thit end of October and met nurse Michelle following weeks back and met Stephen - genius in every sense of the word.  
November in A&E I met Dr Permane and nurse Brouegh. Again professional in every way. So human and bedside manner outstanding I cannot praise the NHS highly enough, especially in these trying times. Thank you from the bottom of my heart

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: yellowxz76
title: Their help is much appreciated
body:
My husband has been unable to attend the Lewis Manning meetings, as, as well as Covid, he is unable now to leave the house. He is having palliative care at home from Agape. Saying that, every Thursday I have a call from one of the lovely staff at LM. Which has been a real help at times, just to know they're there to help is much appreciated. We've had very thoughtful boxes of gifts, and although he can't appreciate them fully, I show him what we have, and he does realise how lovely they all are. We have met Mandy, Lisa and Nigel in person, as they have popped in to see us.  
He has Parkinsons and some dementia, and is steadily deteriorating, but his humour still shines through at times. I am hoping to have my husband at home to take care of, for as long as possible, along with the help of carers and members of our family.

author: giftgd98
title: Two birthing experiences
body:
In October 2020 I delivered my second baby in daisy Hill hospital. The labour was a little dramatic as my waters broke at home and were full of meconium so I had to be induced as soon as possible. My midwife, Arlene, was fantastic and allowed me complete control over my whole labour. She kept me informed the whole time and my husband was with me from word go.  
Unfortunately this experience was a far cry from my first labour in 2019 which was awful. Again I had to be induced as baby was 11 days over term. I was induced by pessary and was promptly ignored for the rest of the day. I asked for pain relief several times and was eventually given gas and air. I was told numerous times I was not in labour even though I was getting regular strong contractions every 3-5minutes. I also asked to be examined and was again told no due to the risk of infection. Unfortunately my baby ended up being born in an examination room on the antenatal ward, and I feel this was the fault of the staff involved. I then had to wheeled back through a packed antenatal ward after the birth of my son. I suffered severe anxiety postnatally which I linked to the traumatic labour.  
So thankfully i did have a far better experience second time round and it was a very healing process for me.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: doradodc84
title: Thank you all so much
body:
Everyone involved in my care from volunteer driver through care assistants to the kitchen staff who prepare us a lovely lunch.  
Thank you all so much.  
The warmth and care everyone shows is like a big cuddle. I always feel as though you all understand any problems I may have and the atmosphere as I come into the hospice is always calming and comfortable.  
Through the pandemic I have felt someone is always there if needed. Your very reassuring weekly calls so welcome when shielding, and now we have Zoom meetings!!  
The Oakhaven Hospice is special and the people there are special too.  
I feel so lucky to have found you all.

author: sagittapb76
title: Vaccine programme
body: Excellent organisation and professional delivery all the team and volunteers were exceptional at south lake Craigavon. Well done all involved!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Leannec23
title: Fantastic staff
body:
My daughter was in medical ward in royal Aberdeen children’s hospital as a day case for a cystoscopy and mcug in January and I just want to thank all the staff for their excellent care. Staff were very organised from the beginning we were immediately shown to her bed space and given paperwork to fill  
Out and within half an hour of being on the ward my daughter was admitted in and we had spoken with the anaesthetist and dr driver. It was good to be able to speak with the anaesthetist as I was able to tell him that my daughter was quite scared of needles after previous investigations requiring a cannula, he ensured they would do the cannula once my daughter was asleep and this was a huge weight off my mind. Staff were all very nice and were excellent with infection control, always cleaning everything, washing their hands and donning and doffing Ppe which was very reassuring to see. My daughter felt so at home that she practically skipped down to theatre with her welly boots on, haha. The student nurse who took us down was fantastic with her and checked I knew how to get back onto the ward. I don’t remember her name I just know she was close to being qualified. As soon as mr driver was finished in theatre he came up and told me his findings and his thoughts which was also very helpful. My daughter was a bit grumpy after anaesthetic mainly because a catheter had to remain in for her scan later on in the day. all the staff down in recovery and back up on the ward were so patient with her. Staff were always making sure she had food or drinks if she needed them, in particular the student nurse from earlier was very attentive and even asked me if I needed anything which was so kind. The nurses tried to get my daughters scan moved forward to save the catheter being in so long but were unable to, we totally understood this and we were grateful for them to try. Play staff made sure my daughter had plenty to keep her occupied with in her bed space anyways. The staff in radiology again were so lovely and my daughter was happy and smiling during her scan which made it far more easier. One of the nurses had arranged for my daughter to get a small toy because of her long day and she was absolutely delighted, hasn’t stopped going on about her twilight sparkle. Every single member of staff went above and beyond for all the children despite being so busy and with the challenges of the pandemic, they all deserve a Medal. My daughter has to come back shortly for another procedure and she isn’t in the slightest bit scared to go and that’s down to these fantastic staff. I also have no doubts that the lovely student nurse who was dealing with us will make a fantastic qualified nurse. Is there any way I can send in something for the staff? I know with current guidelines this might be difficult. Even if I may make a donation and some sweets or something be bought for staff on the ward as I would really like to give back to the lovely staff. We have made a small donation to the Archie foundation also.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Office of Stewart Stevenson, MSP for Banffshire and Buchan Coast

author: Tom555
title: My journey with bowel cancer
body:
First diagnosed in September which was a bit of a shock from then had many trips to hospital. Had operation in November then several weeks of after care . I have just started Chemotherapy  
First of four sessions so hopefully that will sort things out for good thank to the NHS

author: TheRegiment-CN
title: Rigid Cystoscopy
body:
Where do I start, from the moment I walked into the Elective Centre, I was cared for, the receptionist downstairs was amazing and friendly, the receptionist upstairs was attentive.  
Then you have the nurses, who as always were lovely, kind, caring and nothing was never too much for them.  
Dr John, was amazing, I can't express my admiration for him, I am a very anxious patient, and he managed to get rid of all my anxiety.  
Then you have the person who took me to the theatre, he was a ray of sunshine, forever smiling.  
Then you the nurses in recovery, what heroes, nothing phases them, always willing to help.  
Then I was moved to Dolphin Ward where I recovered. The sister there is a credit to the NHS, caring, compassionate, funny and a great leader, and Carlos, the man who makes you happy just by looking at him, he would always stop to make sure I was okay,listened to my concerns and never judged me. A lovely man.  
I can’t say thanks enough to all the wonderful NHS workers in the Elective Centre at Croydon Hospital, and I wish I could name you all, you are heroes, you are stepping up to help where others would run, you care about others when there is so many self-centred people about, they say that not all true heroes wear capes, and this certainly proves it to me. Stay safe you wonderful people of the NHS.  
On a general note to everyone who works in Croydon University Hospital and the whole of the NHS. We as a country will never be able to repay you for your selfless acts you are doing everyday, from the admin staff book appointments, the receptionist who are the face of the NHS, the porters who are the backbone of the NHS, the doctors who are facing the pandemic head on, never budging never wavering, saving lives. And the nurses, who are being pushed to the limit, dealing with horrors only a few can relate too, holding the hands of of patients in their last moments of their lives, being the ones who bear the brunt of everyone’s frustration, you are heroes, you are amazing, you give hope, you are angels, you are all loved. Thank you!!!💙💙💙

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Music409
title: Toenail removal
body: I had toenail removal surgery this week to resolve an ingrown issue I had been dealing with for 4 months. I was quite apprehensive as I’ve never had many procedures done before, but the podiatrists were so kind and really helped explain the benefits to me and help me feel relaxed throughout. I really want to thank the staff for making this such a positive experience for me.

author: correspondenceep49
title: Very thorough service
body: I came in for my vaccine today and was very impressed with the team. I had an allergy to penicillin when I was younger and was impressed at the lady doing my jab. Who made sure I absolutely didn't have any severe reactions. All very friendly and felt like a very safe experience.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Joloneill.
title: Covid vaccine session at South Lake Centre
body: Had vaccine. Brilliant set up. Staff fantastic and very professional

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: PaulF1969
title: Received the Covid vaccine
body: I was very happy and relieved that it went very well

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Johng21
title: Drinking
body:
I have been over drinking for around 3 years, and since I have been attending the Inclusion with Stepping Stones Aldershot, I have felt that I have more control and think very differently about how I drink.
The experience has really helped me think about how I consume alcohol.
Peter and his team have really been a lifeline and massive support to me!
Cant thank them enough.

author: The Cobbler
title: Vaccination for Covid
body: A nurse gave me an injection. I was waiting for it to happen and it was over. Brilliant! !

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: sw2021
title: Covid 19 vaccination
body: It was over before I knew it nurse chatted away and it was all over in a matter of seconds. Very well organised I felt safe and the venue was perfect plenty of space and extremely clean overall 100% a credit to staff and management alike 😊 I feel grateful.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Downport
title: Staff to be highly praised
body: I went to South Lakes Leisure Centre Craigavon for my Covid 19 vaccine. Ample parking facilities in front of entrance. A very well organised system in operation for processing individuals to receive their vaccination. Friendly staff showing an interest In ones welfare. The 15 minute precaution care for any reaction to vaccine at the end did slow things down. Despite how busy the centre was I was out in under 1 hour. Organisation and staff to be highly praised and even more so considering many were volunteers.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: rainpd83
title: First Response Bradford
body:
My wife took her own life recently.  
She called First Response Bradford numerous times in 2019/20 asking for intensive therapy and even hospitalisation due to her suicidal thoughts.  
Every single member of staff at that so called service were rude, condescending and treated her like a problem, not like she had a problem that needed to be helped with kindness and compassion.  
On one occasion, after yet another point-blank refusal to help her in a suicidal crisis, I asked the alleged professional on the phone that, given that they were refusing to help her, again, would they accept responsibility if she harmed herself. A fair question in the circumstances, no?  
I was told by the woman at First Response that I was -being manipulative.  
This is completely unacceptable for a trained MH practitioner to say this. Her bedside manner and compassion was not fit for the post.  
Every time she called First Response in the height of a suicidal crisis she was either told to go to A&E, call 111 or just asked whether I was home to look after her. Every time, First Response and BDCT devolved their responsibilty and even one time told me, her husband with no MH qualifications and a full time job that her care was my responsibilty. They even once called me whilst I was at work to ask me to go home and look after her. I did, obviously, but if they felt she was at such risk, is it not the job of MH practitioners to provide appropriate care and support, including fast-track treatment?  
These people in my experience were heartless, compassionless, unprofessional, jaded, disinterested and, I believe, more bothered about inpatient bed-pressures than actually helping people who want to end their own lives.  
Suffice to say, my wife came away from every call to them feeling even worse than before she had called.  
Additionally, when she was seen by an alleged pychiatrist, at Lynfield Mount, they told her they were discharging her because, -She didn't look depressed. After one meeting, I believe. What qualified Doctor can say something like this. Maybe if she had turned up covered in her own urine, chain-smoking and looking unkempt they might have helped as presumably they only treat people who -look depressed, whatever that means.  
The entire service is not fit for purpose in my experience.  
My wife is now dead as a result of suicide.  
Perhaps if the people who get paid a decent wage to support people with depression and suicidal thoughts (and also have a statutory duty of care) had taken her seriously rather than argue with her and label her as argumentative and uncooperative she may be alive today. She may still have taken her own life, but this lot did nothing to help her and basically treated her as though she was being dramatic and attention-seeking.  
Also, it's amazing how fast BDCT's Serious Incident Team contacted me after her death.  
If only BDCT would respond to patients' and family's pleas for help and support with such expedience and efficiency before they die rather than after.  
The only way First Response can help the local community in my experience is if it was disbanded, and the money put to better use.

readBy.name: Bradford District Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: blackbirdbf85
title: COVID vaccination delay
body: I consented to receive two doses of a Covid-19 vaccine, 3 weeks apart. My appointment for the second vaccination has been postponed to 10 weeks after the first dose. The vaccine manufacturers do not stand over this dosing regimen. As a frontline healthcare worker, dealing with COVID positive patients every day, this is a real kick in the teeth.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: AnnS
title: Getting my  vaccine
body: Very well organised and enjoyed the experience from start to finish. Met at the door by a lovely volunteer, queuing system in place with staff telling you where to stand. Reception staff very pleasant and efficient even though it was very busy, and not everyone being cooperative with them. I witnessed quite a few people being rude even though the staff were trying their best to check their documents. Quite a long wait in the waiting are but still well organise. Vaccinators were very good and I hardly felt it. Very professional set up and was a pleasant experience.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: lo9564
title: Vaccination
body: I had my first COVID-19 vaccine. The team were well organized and professional. I was anxious about getting my jab buy my vaccinator was calm and reassuring and helped make my experience as good as it could be!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: telescopiumcc95
title: Receiving care on a broken leg
body: Went in to have surgery on a broken leg. The care I received off the nurses and all staff I came across was exceptional

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: BH Comment
title: Negative experience from start to finish
body:
My experience with Ballenden House was almost entirely negative from start to finish.  
I received a letter from them a few months before the date of my first appointment stating that I was going to be removed from the waiting list for failing to attend my appointment. They had rescheduled my initial appointment at short notice and then, it seems, failed to inform me of the new date. This was not a one-off issue. My second appointment was cancelled on the morning it was scheduled to take place and further appointments were disrupted by poor time management and lateness (not mine!).  
I could excuse these administrative issues if the appointments themselves had been adequate. The level of care I received from this service was far from acceptable. The people who carried out my assessments seemed to lack basic knowledge, told me things about my condition and medication which are objectively false, disregarded and downplayed the very symptoms that I was seeking help for (because they were severely affecting my functioning and wellbeing), and continuously twisted what I'd told them when relaying things back to me.  
I felt like they decided early on what my 'problem' was and then tried to shoehorn all of my history and symptoms into that diagnosis. I tried to push back on their framing (which was difficult as I felt vulnerable and not listened to) and explain that I did not think that their diagnosis accounted for the symptoms I was seeking help for but my attempts were unsuccessful. I accept that patients do not always know best; however, their preferred diagnosis was not only a bad fit for my symptoms but didn't lead to any sort of further treatment that would address them. Further, they told me that it wasn't really necessary to undergo a formal diagnostic assessment as 'if you do have it, it's only mild'. The symptoms I was seeking help for were not mild-- that's why I was seeking help!  
I left Ballenden House feeling exponentially worse than when I arrived with no diagnosis or signposting to treatment, and no indication of what I should do next.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: GRIFFCL17
title: Excellent NHS 24 service
body:
I had called my GP on Thursday and received excellent care from.the Nurse Practitioner who prescribed antibiotics for a UTI. On Saturday my symptoms worsened and I phoned NHS 24. I went through the automated process of going through symptoms so I was directed to the correct area and then very quickly spoke with call handler Ian. Ian was very thoughrough in going through symptoms, what had changed, what was worse etc. He then passed the call on to the nurse on shift - Audrey - who again went through everything, and said a clinician would give me a call within a 2 hour window and they would decide if I had to be seen. Both Audrey and Ian were very efficient, quick and friendly.  
Within 15 minutes of finishing the call to NHS 24, a clinician based at Stobhill called me back to discuss. The Dr again went through everything and agreed antibiotics needed to be changed and for a longer course. She electronically sent this to my local pharmacy so that I didnt have to travel far to collect.  
All in all this whole process took 30 minutes and all staff I spoke to were pleasant, understanding and very quick to help. Thank you.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Mental health user
title: Referral system to Adult Mental Health Care
body:
I have been a service user of mental health services for the past 15 years, firstly in Early Intervention, Adult Mental Health and Perinatal and under GP care. I have complex psychiatric issues and have been an inpatient on two occasions.  
After being 'lost' in the mental health system my GP was unable to prescribe medication required to manage a condition until he received confirmation from a psychiatrist.  
My mental health care plan is also lost and out of date.  
Today I attended a referral appointment to regain access to services.  
I was very distressed as my patient history questionnaire, that I have completed on several occasions was not accessed prior my appointment.  
I had not received any communication to warn me that I would be expected to provide a full historical debrief at this meeting.  
As a consequence lots of traumatic experiences that have happened was revisited purely because the clinicians who were completing my referral hadn't read my notes nor copied over this assessment to my file.  
I was very agitated and distressed during my appointment to have to discuss historical abuse which is a major trigger for my severe psychiatric illness just to gain access to adult mental health services of which I have been a service user for 15 years.  
The whole referral system is flawed and has made my psychological state worse.  
I am still waiting until they review my case next week until they decide on the appropriate referral, I. E. GP lead, community based or as an outpatient and this distress could have been avoided by pre populating these questionnaires by information already held.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: mayps64
title: So thankful I took this step
body: I have experienced many things in my lifetime including loss as most people do. However when a friend was assaulted and left with life changing injuries, I didn’t know how to deal with it. This left me with many feelings of anger and guilt and I couldn’t comprehend why it was happening to someone who was so good and kind! The feelings that I felt simmered away inside me and this started to cause issues for me at work. All of this alongside the lockdown for Coronavirus impacted my mental health to the point where I could see no way out. When it got to the point where I couldn’t attend work I knew I had to do something. I looked for counselling and found Inclusion Thurrock and I started my counselling within a couple of weeks and it is the best thing I have ever done. Counselling was always something that I never thought I would do. It is my worst nightmare as I never open up to people but this was different. I was at the point where I was ready to change things and the support and guidance I received from my counsellor was impeccable. I started off well and then had a set back but with the help of my counsellor I was back to myself within 3mths. I am building up my resilience now with some extra online support but I feel like a new person and am so thankful that I took this step!

author: Alison73
title: Overall, an excellent experience!
body: I was an inpatient in ward 23B for 4 weeks following removal of a spinal cord tumour. I can only describe the care as outstanding particularly as we were in the midst of a pandemic. Everyone from the nurses, doctors, students, porters, physios and OT all demonstrated so much compassion and kindness and were always so cheerful and encouraging. They work so well together and should be so proud. Overall, an excellent experience!

author: jams50
title: Very pleasant staff
body:
Very pleasantly treated on my first visit to this hospital.  
Staff were very polite and friendly.  
Ultrasound staff were particularly welcoming and efficient.  
I even found a parking spot (which my friends don't believe).

author: frostps97
title: Keep up the good work team :-)
body: There has probably never been a more difficult time to have your loved ones requiring hospital care. Physical visits were the means to keep abreast of progress and to keep the patient in good spirits. The virtual visiting service clearly cannot equal that but it is the next best thing. The people managing this service and providing the calls are doing a wonderful job in these uncertain times - keep up the good work team: -)

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Beemallon
title: Virtual call with patient
body:
Booking through the virtual team has been a real pleasant experience.
Considering how busy the team must be they are so helpful with our bookings.
Gillian, Dominic and Mairead (I hope I heard maireads name right earlier today! ) have been great and their help much appreciated to us as a family.
Although the line wasn't working earlier, when I did get through, making the bookings for this weekend was a breeze.
Thank you all

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamh 1
title: White abbey Nightingale Hospital
body:
I got out of bed slipped and fell when going to make my breakfast.  
I ended up in Musgrave park hospital. I tested positive for COVID 19. Then Musgrave sent me here (Whiteabbey Nightingale) for more improvement and more therapy to get me back to walking since I had an accident.  
I wasn’t happy about falling and catching COVID. But I had to get on with it and realised the people here are nice. I would love to go home but I need to get rid of this disease first.  
Some positives from my stay here:  
very good teamwork  
i was always taken to the toilet on time  
empowered to do what i need to improve my walking  
physiotherapist was helpful to help my walking  
modified diet to prevent choking  
food is very nice  
good staff skills  
very happy with the night staff  
night staff are very nice people  
nice care staff generally  
enough privacy good staff attitudes and introductions  
staff always there to help  
staff make an effort to go the extra mile  
good treatment and medications managed well  
good nurses and doctors  
everything is explained well  
like the tv and I could read books and do puzzles.  
Some areas for improvement:  
I am a bit too cold at times  
keeping personal belongings safe  
would like to make video call not just phone calls  
video calling family would help mental health  
more regularly updated on when i can go home  
more staffing for doctors  
better access to turning off ac

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust
Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Molly blue
title: Visit to ambulatory care
body:
Anxious to begin with havingaacurretage from the side of my nose. Did not have to worry I was put at ease straight away. David who was in charge told me what would happen How the injections might be painful the operation was done efficiently with the help of two medical assistants. He explained to them asked questions about what was happening. It was interesting. David was making witty comments that me relax . The op was done with David explaining all the way. Then he explained what would happen after the op. On the whole what I was afraid of was not  
Due to the op team of David,Kevin and jemina  
[Unsure about 'Reception']

author: Busdriver101
title: Told to leave by the receptionist
body:
After trying to speak to a receptionist on the telephone for over half an hour I eventually went to my practice for a letter for the pharmacy to get a rescue pack to treat my wife infected exacerbation for COPD. I was greeted by a very rude receptionist who shouted get out I tried to explain what I needed. The receptionist continued to talk over me and repeated get out can you not read, we are in a pandemic!  
This is no way to speak to anyone, they didn't know even know what my issue was. They clearly state they do don't tolerate abuse, are they allowed to verbally abuse their patients? Yes, I am fully aware we in a pandemic and yes I can read. All I ask is please be a bit more kinder as we are all trying to get through life during these unprecedented times.

author: Moki
title: All went exactly to plan in Day Surgery
body: Having broken my wrist on a Saturday. I went to A& E at Hairmyres hospital as it is my local hospital. Every member of staff there were absolutely brilliant. In short I was given ketamine and a plaster cast was put on my wrist. Unfortunately not the end of story. At 9am on Sunday I received a call from Wishaw general to inform me that they would try to fit me in for surgery that day if possible. Another call at dinner time to apologise for being rushed off their feet. I was kept informed on Monday both am and pm. The very nice girl on pm call said I was pencilled in for 7. 30am on Wednesday and would get another call on Tuesday at dinner time to confirm. This call was received was received at 5. 20 with all relevant information and another at 7. 25 ish with even more details about emergencies coming in at last minute and such like. This call was from one of the nurses that I met on Wednesday. All went exactly to plan and and every single one of the staff were absolutely brilliant. The care was excellent everything was explained and they were all marvellous. I am nearly 72 years old and thankfully do not have much experience of operations or broken bones.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Amazing Day Surgery
body: My umbilical hernia op was carried out far quicker than if I’d waited for my local hospital. Shepton provided a perfect stress free experience. From my initial contact, to my previsits, being greeted at the door, meeting the team carrying out the op. Chatting with the anaesthetist (who was amazingly calming). Everyone was friendly, informative and made me feel at ease. Everyone had the best ‘bedside manner’...no exceptions. Can’t thank you all enough. Even the warmed blankets were a welcome surprise.

title: Excellent practice
body:
Receptionists at the surgery are polite and helpful and because of Covid, had a very good chat on the telephone, with a caring and understanding dr, instead of going in person to the surgery. 
I appreciated the time that I was given, to talk about my concerns , considering how overwhelmed with calls arranging visits and jabs, the practice must be at the moment.

author: A satisfied couple
title: Satisfied couple after Covid Vaccination
body:
Both my Husband and myself have had our vaccinations at the Belgrave Medical Centre, 22 Asline Road Sheffield and would like to praise everyone there for making such an easy and pleasant experience. On arrival we were guided into the car park, then asked all the relevant questions, next told where to go inside and after a short wait very soon vaccinated. I personally have a phobia with needles and mentioned this to a very understanding nurse, I felt her rub my arm and straight away she said right that is it, I have to say I was aware it was on its way but didn't feel a thing. If only any injections I have in the future could be like this one my problems would be over.  
Really I would like to say whoever organised this should be very proud. Also everyone was wonderful, the volunteers both outside and in, the doctors and nurses.  
Well done all of you.

author: CG1964
title: Minor injuries unit
body:
This week I had a scald to my chest area. I pitched in to minor injuries the following morning. The area is spotless, reception staff helpful and I was issued with a fresh mask for my consultation. Seen quickly and had area cleaned and dressed. Follow up appointment the following day managed in the same way. Staff were helpful, caring and friendly. Booked again for Sunday but told I could pitch in any time. Took them at their word this morning due to pain and no further dressings at home.  
Was seen by a nurse practitioner called Linda. I was in a bit of a state but was made to feel that they cared. My dressings were reviewed and changed. Linda also referred me to the burns clinic for review. Thanks folks you really don't know just how much I appreciated your care this morning. This is a fantastic local resource run by very capable nursing staff. Thank you .

author: TM123
title: Amazing staff and care
body: My father was admitted to Causeway Hospital, Coleraine with Covid-19 last Sunday. Due to the excellent expertise and sincere care of all staff, from the Paramedic team, to the Emergency Department, to the Medical Assessment ward, my father made a remarkable recovery and is now back home. A huge “thank you” from all the family for your kindness and care. We are sincerely grateful.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Manda do
title: I’m alcoholic
body: When got here I was in a dark place, I have been lucky enough to have a detox and feel well and confident to go home. The staff here are amazing they work so hard, I am so grateful and now looking forward to my future, THANKYOU

author: pepperzf53
title: Not gone back to alcohol
body:
Excellent service  
Really helpful  
Not gone back to Alcohol since engaging with S.T.A.R.S

author: slideke74
title: An amazing service manager
body:
I want to say a big thank you to Paul of CGL Cambridgeshire area.  
You are an amazing service manager been through all the changes your under penning staff have worked hard and long hours  
And still stand strong as a humorous, stable supporting member of the team

author: deploymentym59
title: An amazing experience
body: I have had a amazing time and experience with my key worker.

author: corvussy65
title: Carer's Day
body: Supportive service

author: nitratekf79
title: Great Hospice
body: Very happy with everything. All staff very helpful. Food very good. Every one very helpful. Can talk about anything that might be troubling you.

author: novembersz43
title: Really helpful keyworker
body: Excellent, my keyworker really helpful, and guided me through

author: Chef chris
title: Reiki
body:
Sarah introduced me to a really calming experience before chemotherapy. making me very at ease and peaceful such a great start to treatment and help calm my nerves on my first treatment.  
Thankyou so much

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: magpienh96
title: Struggling with alcohol usage due to my past
body:
I suffered some traumas in my childhood. I contacted my Doctor, whom put me in touch with inclusions and then I was allocated Peter in Aldershot as my key worker.
I have been attending Three meetings a week with Peter, all to give me coping strategies to help me reduce and eventually stop drinking. Peter is supportive as are the other service users and I have gained many coping strategies to aid me. I feel listened to and I don't feel alone anymore. I know I pick up the phone or email Peter when I am struggling and he will respond with empathy and without judgement.

author: julycs43
title: Still clean
body:
Support has been ok, still clean, have found the staff helpful.  
Also gave me the necessary tools to keep going

author: quebeczd34
title: It met my needs
body:
Very useful can not see anyway it can be improved  
The support met my needs at a time of great hardship

author: firens86
title: Not drinking as much
body: Helped a lot, still drinking but not as much as was.

author: chamaeleonmy94
title: A different perspective
body: Started taking drugs as fun. Then life came unbearable, unable to recognise myself or my actions. Reaching out to S. T. A. R. S. and their help gave me a different perspective.
